text: Underlining the importance of information and communications technology in meeting the growing demands of the Organization as it becomes increasingly reliant on its information technology and communications infrastructure,

text: Recognizes the need for central authority to set common standards, provide an Organization-wide perspective, optimize use of resources and improve information and communications technology services;

text: Also recognizes the need for an integrated, global information system that makes possible the effective management of human, financial and physical resources and that is based on streamlined business processes and best practices;

text: Further recognizes the need for a global operational framework to enable the United Nations to respond effectively to emergency situations that may impair the operations of critical elements of its information and communications technology infrastructure and facilities;
textWithHighlights: *Further recognizes* the need for a global operational framework to enable the {{United Nations}} to respond effectively to emergency situations that may impair the operations of critical elements of its information and communications technology infrastructure and facilities;

text: Information and communications technology strategy and governance
Recognizing the importance of the Secretary-General’s knowledge management proposals, particularly in facilitating more informed decision-making and improving the effectiveness of the Organization,

text: Enterprise resource planning project

Recalls section II, paragraph 4, of its resolution 60/283, in which it decided to replace the Integrated Management Information System with a next-generation enterprise resource planning system or other comparable system;
textWithHighlights: *Recalls* section II, paragraph 4, of its resolution 60/283, in which it decided to replace the Integrated Management Information System with a next-generation enterprise resource planning system or other comparable system;

text: Stresses that the implementation of the enterprise resource planning system should aim at consolidating the management of all financial, human and physical resources under a single integrated information system for the entire Organization, including for peacekeeping and field missions;
textWithHighlights: *Stresses* that the implementation of the enterprise resource planning system should aim at consolidating the management of all financial, human and physical resources under a single integrated information system for the entire {{Organization}}, including for peacekeeping and field missions;
uncertainties: No assignee is explicitly tasked. The phrase about consolidating management under a single integrated system is treated as an objective rather than a concrete deliverable because it is framed as what the implementation "should aim" to achieve.

text: Recognizes the considerable operational and financial risks involved in the implementation of the enterprise resource planning system, and stresses the need for the Secretary-General to ensure full accountability and clear lines of responsibility for the project;
textWithHighlights: *Recognizes* the considerable operational and financial risks involved in the implementation of the enterprise resource planning system, and *stresses* the need for the {{Secretary-General}} to ensure full accountability and clear lines of responsibility for the project;
uncertainties: The phrase 'stresses the need for the Secretary-General to ensure...' references the Secretary-General but is not a direct directive (e.g., 'requests'), so the Secretary-General is treated as a mentioned entity rather than an assignee; no deliverable is extracted.

text: Stresses the need to implement the various functions of the enterprise resource planning system across the global range of United Nations offices in a well-planned, step-by-step manner that ensures adequate preparation and training for each location and that minimizes the burden of change on the Organization and its resources, in order to further mitigate organizational and managerial risks;
